description: From Middle English bareyne, from Anglo-Norman baraigne, baraing (“sterile; barren”), of obscure origin; probably from a Germanic language, perhaps Frankish *baʀ (“bare; barren”), from Proto-Germanic *bazaz (“bare”). If so, a doublet of bare.

adjectives.description: barren (comparative barrener or more barren, superlative barrenest or most barren)

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Unable to bear children; sterile.
examples: I silently wept as my daughter's husband rejected her. What would she do now that she was no longer a maiden but also barren?

entries.meaning: Of poor fertility, infertile; not producing vegetation.

examples: But schemes are perfectly accidental. Some will appear barren of hints and matter, but prove to be fruitful.

entries.meaning: An area of low fertility and habitation, a desolate place.
examples: The pine barrens are a site lonely enough to suit any hermit.
